utterances: Absolutely.
And that's one reason why it has taken so long for the administration to get to a decision because it's been subject to many rigorous environmental reviews, economic reviews, state and local reviews.
And again, there's this kind of balance that the State Department would have to make.
You know, the possible threat of some local contamination or some small or medium local spill versus what would be the broader benefit for national interest or the economy.
And here's an email from Steve.
Many thousands of more jobs in solar or wind where they are needed at the point of energy use.
In other words, why are we developing oil when we could be developing alternative technologies?

You know, something I recently learned that's very interesting is there are actually more than twice as many jobs in the renewable energy industry in the United States than there are in the fossil fuel industry.

There's - according to a study by the Brookings Institution done over the summer, there are 2.7 million jobs in the United States in the renewable energy industry and only about 800,000 in coal, oil and other fossil fuel extraction; which is interesting, you know, it's surprising to, you know, understand that discrepancy in numbers.

And this project is expected to bring, you know, two to 5,000 additional jobs, which is, you know, not insignificant but it's a small - it's a much smaller number than the number of jobs in the renewable energy industry.
And this from Stan in Geneva, New York.
It's my understanding the oil from the Excel pipeline goes to Texas in order to be exported.
How does exporting this oil make us less energy dependent?
Exactly.
That's one of the issues.
I mean, it's not - there's no guarantee in building this pipeline that the supply actually come - will come directly to the United States.
There will be new supply entering the global market, and that will be produced - you know, the demand for that supply will come from North America, potentially reduce demand from the Middle East.
But, you know, the oil market is really global, and so, you know, it's not a guarantee that this will be injected directly into the U.S.
market.
And there's no guarantee whatsoever that will make any difference in oil prices or gasoline prices in the United States.
All of those are influenced by global developments around the world.
So all of this comes into play when you think about whether or not it's a good decision to do it.
So in some ways, it's symbolic, but symbols are important.
Yes.

And the fact that it's so symbolic is so clear if you look at the history, if you look at how this, you know, sat as a backburner issue until we were approaching a heavily contested presidential election.
All of a sudden, you know, it became something being touted by the campaigns.
And until 1,000 protests said...
Yes.
...I'm willing to go to jail to protest the Keystone XL Pipeline.
Coral Davenport, thanks very much for being with us today.
It's a pleasure.
Coral Davenport, energy and environment correspondent for National Journal.
As we mentioned, Ken Rudin, political junkie, are on the road to Des Moines next week, so join us for that.
I think, I've heard that one.
Mark Jordan Legan is a writer living in Los Angeles.
A youthful writer.
Well, he may have fewer reviews to parse, because there are fewer movie critics out there these days.
New papers are losing staffs, so are news magazines.
Newsweek just announced that 111 staffers are taking the magazine's buyout offer.
One of them is - one of the best known of those staffers is the movie critic, David Ansen.
David Ansen, came to our studios earlier this week to speak with my colleague Alex Chadwick.
I think everyone's identity is tied to their work.
So if you are leaving the place where you worked for quite a long time, it is a loss of identity, but with you it's a very public identity.
Well, that's true.
But let me clarify a little bit, because I'm not actually leaving Newsweek.
I've entered in to a contract with the magazine to continue writing for them starting next year in January.
Obviously, not quite as often, but I will be regularly weighing in on the major movies after this new deal comes into place.
So, I'll probably be doing about a dozen pieces a year.
So, it's kind of - I think of it is a kind of halfway house for movie addicted critics.
You know, the New York Times just ran a piece this week saying movie critics all over the place are on their way out, out of newspapers, out of magazines.
There is a disturbing trend.
I mean, as the Times' piece noted a lot of people have lost their positions, just very recently either through buyouts or they've been fired.
But the general point is true, there is obviously, because of the web, the Internet, it is seemingly becoming an endangered species.
When you see that media world changing, you sound as though you are going into it willingly...
Mm hm.
but willing or not, you don't quite know what the heck is going to happen and what you're going to do.
That's true, true.
You know I think there is great uncertainty out there, as the media field changes so rapidly.
And it really worries people in the movie industry - in a criticism, in terms of its economic impact on the movie business.

It has very little influence over the big blockbusters, the big Hollywood, you know, it doesn't really matter what critics think of the latest ""Pirates of the Caribbean."" But for foreign films, for independent films, for out of the way things, you know, a review in a national magazine can really help and make a difference.
So I think there is great alarm in the independent world about what's going on in the reduction of print criticism.
Here you are in the media world as a writer, covering another form of media which itself is in great transition here.
Yes, yes.
Yeah there's huge changes going on partly because of technology.
Because of filming on digital, there is actually a lot more product because it's cheaper to produce.
There is a kind of an avalanche of independent movies and it's making it harder and harder for them to distinguish themselves.
The number of movies that open week-by-week can be overwhelming.
Hillel Neuer is with U.N Watch, a group affiliated with the American Jewish Committee that's often critical of the United Nations.
That's it.
To push roughly and a garden tool.
No wasteful spending.
No spending on toys that we don't need.
You know, the kids have a million toys.
They don't need that.
We need clothes, you know.
We need food and clothing.
That's going to be it for the most part, you know.
For, I think, the rest of the family, yes, smaller things.
Not those big ticket items, per se, unless the sale is really good.
You know, big.
That's why all those stores are trumpeting their sales here.
And when shoppers feel nervous, business owners really feel it.
Just off the main drag of this mall is a jewelry boutique.
It's called Blanca Flor.
Donna De Garcia owns this store and another in downtown Annapolis.
She specializes in silver jewelry and gifts from Mexico.
De Garcia says it was back in September that it first started to sink in just how bad this crisis could be.
I was in Mexico in September buying up half the town, you know, and on a road trip to replenish my decorative arts.
I came back to the surprise that the downtown store had sold something like 41 percent less as compared to the year before.
Wow.
So, that was a really terrible month.
And that scared me.
And luckily the numbers went back up a little bit.
But it's pretty slow right now.
So, you know, there's been some scary months and some scary weeks.
As I look around the store, the back shelves are packed full of these beautiful platters and dishes and decorative items.
And the cases, the glass cases, are full of jewelry.
I mean, you have a lot of product in this store.
And let's hope somebody comes and buys it this holiday, or I'm going to be up the creek in January.
You're crossing your fingers, right?
I am crossing both my fingers.
How much of a cushion do you have?
What happens if this holiday season is really bad?
You know, I hate to say it, but I don't have a lot of a cushion.
You know, it's very stressful.
If this is a really bad Christmas, what will it mean for your business?
What would you have to go do?

Oh, I probably would have to not go to the show in New York in January to buy for spring and just sell jewelry that I have left over, and keep working on selling the things that I bought that I was supposed to sell over the holidays.
That makes me think that the wholesalers then wouldn't get your business?
The wholesalers are suffering.
I got a letter from one of my jewelry designers company, fairly large company, today saying that they had a lot of - over 500 items ten percent off and over a thousand items 20 percent off.
So when you get letters like that, you know that they're hurting.
And I also was going to cancel two orders from two companies, and they told me take it, take it, send me back what you don't sell.
So I know that, you know, that's where the chain starts, is with the wholesalers.
They're already suffering.
Yeah.
Is there a difference for you?
What have you done to prepare yourself for this season that's different than last season?
Have you hired the same number of people to work it?
Are you...
We've cut down on our payroll a few times this year.
You know, cut down on the number of people that were in the store at certain times of the day.
But to prepare for this season, unfortunately, what I did is go out and buy too much.
(Soundbite of laughter)
So...
Wow.
I wasn't expecting as sudden of a dramatic economic crisis.
I think everybody knew that, you know, the mortgage thing had already started, the real estate thing was starting to fall.
But most people weren't prepared for the drama that we've just experienced.
But I'm hopeful.
It's not the end of the world.
If I have a fairly good Christmas, I'll get by.
What I'm more worried about is if things don't improve and we see nobody shopping for months like January, February, March, April.
And that's what I'm a little bit concerned about, is making it through the winter.
Donna De Garcia the owner of Blanca Flor.
This is a boutique here that specializes in silver jewelry and gifts.
Thank you so much for letting us talk to you.
Well, thank you for coming.
It's nice to see you.
And you can also see the shape of another kind of car coming to a dealership near you called the Smart car.
Yesterday, DaimlerChrysler announced plans to start selling the egg-shaped vehicle in New York, Boston, L.A., Seattle, parts of Florida, and Puerto Rico.
It has two seats and is just nine feet long from bumper to bumper.
